articles.headline: IBM Develops a New Chip That Functions Like a Brain
articles.snippet: The processor, named TrueNorth, may eventually excel at calculations that stump today’s supercomputers.
articles.abstract: The processor, named TrueNorth, may eventually excel at calculations that stump today’s supercomputers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Inspired by the architecture of the brain, scientists have developed a new kind of computer chip that uses no more power than a hearing aid and may eventually excel at calculations that stump today’s supercomputers.

articles.headline: In Ambitious Bid, Walmart Seeks Foothold in Primary Care Services
articles.snippet: Walmart is looking to grab a bigger share of the billions of health care dollars being spent in the United States and to benefit from the shifting delivery system that has resulted from the Affordable Care Act.
articles.abstract: Walmart is looking to grab a bigger share of the billions of health care dollars being spent in the United States and to benefit from the shifting delivery system that has resulted from the Affordable Care Act.
articles.lead_paragraph: Welcome to Walmart. The nurse will be right with you.

articles.headline: Upstart Bank in China Rides High on Technology I.P.O. Crest
articles.snippet: Fan Bao, the head of the China Renaissance investment firm, has built a network of contacts with a focus on tech start-ups that will thrive in China’s “new economy.”
articles.abstract: Fan Bao, the head of the China Renaissance investment firm, has built a network of contacts with a focus on tech start-ups that will thrive in China’s “new economy.”
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — When Alan Guo was chief strategist at Google China, he would have leisurely conversations with Fan Bao, a Beijing banker, exchanging ideas about the future of the Internet in China and swapping gossip about industry personalities. Mr. Bao, who had been a strategist at a Chinese technology company before setting up his own boutique investment bank in 2004, would occasionally prod Mr. Guo about his plans.

articles.headline: Plot Thickens as 900 Writers Battle Amazon
articles.snippet: Douglas Preston, a Hachette author, wrote a letter to his readers asking them to contact Jeff Bezos. Nearly 1,000 other writers have joined his cause.
articles.abstract: Douglas Preston, a Hachette author, wrote a letter to his readers asking them to contact Jeff Bezos. Nearly 1,000 other writers have joined his cause.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROUND POND, Me. — Out here in the woods, at the end of not one but two dirt roads, in a shack equipped with a picture of the Dalai Lama, a high-speed data line and a copy of Thoreau’s “Civil Disobedience,” Amazon’s dream of dominating the publishing world has run into some trouble.

articles.headline: Stampede of Mergers Could Mean Growth, or Irrationality, Ahead
articles.snippet: Cheap credit, lower tax bills and a desire for revenue, more than economic optimism, may be behind this year’s surge in corporate acquisitions.
articles.abstract: Cheap credit, lower tax bills and a desire for revenue, more than economic optimism, may be behind this year’s surge in corporate acquisitions.
articles.lead_paragraph: Something big is happening on Wall Street that is making investment bankers richer. It is also supposed to signal better times ahead for the rest of the country.
articles.byline: By Peter Eavis and David Gelles

articles.headline: ‘Don’t Touch the Walls’: Ebola Fears Infect an African Hospital
articles.snippet: Some Ebola patients still die at a Sierra Leone hospital, but just as many, if not more, are dying in the city and neighboring villages, increasing the risk of the disease’s spread.
articles.abstract: Some Ebola patients still die at a Sierra Leone hospital, but just as many, if not more, are dying in the city and neighboring villages, increasing the risk of the disease’s spread.
articles.lead_paragraph: KENEMA, Sierra Leone — So many patients, nurses and health workers have died in the government hospital that many people in this city, a center of the world’s worst Ebola epidemic, see it as a death trap.

articles.headline: Obama, With Reluctance, Returns to Action in Iraq
articles.snippet: After months of resisting sending Americans to fight ISIS, President Obama on Thursday night found himself exactly where he did not want to be.
articles.abstract: After months of resisting sending Americans to fight ISIS, President Obama on Thursday night found himself exactly where he did not want to be.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In sending warplanes back into the skies over Iraq, President Obama on Thursday night found himself exactly where he did not want to be. Hoping to end the war in Iraq, Mr. Obama became the fourth president in a row to order military action in that graveyard of American ambition.

articles.headline: New Fighting a Bid for Leverage as a Gaza Cease-Fire Expires
articles.snippet: Israel and Palestinian militants resumed cross-border air assaults after a three-day cease-fire expired, but the renewed violence seemed less about meeting military goals than about jockeying for leverage in talks that had made little progress.
articles.abstract: Israel and Palestinian militants resumed cross-border air assaults after a three-day cease-fire expired, but the renewed violence seemed less about meeting military goals than about jockeying for leverage in talks that had made little progress.
articles.lead_paragraph: GAZA CITY — Israel and Palestinian militants in the Gaza Strip resumed cross-border air assaults after a three-day cease-fire expired on Friday, but the renewed violence seemed less about meeting military goals than about jockeying for leverage in talks that had made little progress toward a more durable truce.
articles.byline: By Jodi Rudoren and Isabel Kershner

articles.headline: Malaysia Steps In to Save Its Reeling National Airline
articles.snippet: The government announced a stock buyback and a restructuring plan for Malaysia Airlines, which has lost two planes this year and is mired in debt.
articles.abstract: The government announced a stock buyback and a restructuring plan for Malaysia Airlines, which has lost two planes this year and is mired in debt.
articles.lead_paragraph: Malaysia Airlines was struggling with growing losses, debt and a troubled business model well before the loss of two of its airplanes this year.

articles.headline: U.S. Jets and Drones Attack Militants in Iraq, Hoping to Stop Advance
articles.snippet: American warplanes launched airstrikes against Sunni militants in northern Iraq on Friday, destroying rebel positions around Erbil, the Kurdish capital.
articles.abstract: American warplanes launched airstrikes against Sunni militants in northern Iraq on Friday, destroying rebel positions around Erbil, the Kurdish capital.
articles.lead_paragraph: DOHUK, Iraq — The United States launched a series of airstrikes against Sunni militants in northern Iraq on Friday, using Predator drones and Navy F-18 fighter jets to destroy rebel positions around the city of Erbil, the American military said Friday.
articles.byline: By Alissa J. Rubin, Tim Arango and Helene Cooper

articles.headline: For Mergers, a Shadow of Antitrust Challenges
articles.snippet: In the cases of Sprint’s abandoned bid for T-Mobile and 21st Century Fox’s scuttled merger with Time Warner, more recent aggressive enforcement efforts seem to be having an effect.
articles.abstract: In the cases of Sprint’s abandoned bid for T-Mobile and 21st Century Fox’s scuttled merger with Time Warner, more recent aggressive enforcement efforts seem to be having an effect.
articles.lead_paragraph: Regulators in Washington won not one but two major merger battles this week — without even firing a shot.
